summary: Income gains are now rising faster for low-wage workers.. The left's apocalyptic economic predictions for the Trump Presidency haven't panned out. title: 'Surfacing' Review: The Past is Ever Present
summary: Kathleen Jamie's new essay collection has two principal themes: the degree to which the natural world is full of vivid juxtapositions-and our tendency to overlook them because we're distracted by the ephemera of everyday life.. On a Train trip north toward Aberdeen, the Scottish poet and naturalist Kathleen Jamie witnessed an arresting optical illusion. As the rail car passed between the North Sea and winter woodlands, a reflection caused the nautical scene to mingle with the forest view from Ms. Jamie's window. "If I narrowed my eyes," she tells readers of "Surfacing," her new collection of essays, "I could see both sea and trees at once. And now there was a ship! A ghostly tanker was sailing over the pine trees."

title: Political Books: Interpreting Clarence Thomas
summary: How to grapple with the justice's unique judicial thought, rather than dwell on his biography.. Corey Robin's"The Enigma of Clarence Thomas" (Metropolitan, 301 pages, $30) doesn't spend much time on Anita Hill's charges against Clarence Thomas, but not because Mr. Robin has any trouble believing them. "Once Anita Hill stepped forward with credible allegations that Thomas had sexually harassed her, and Thomas denied them," he writes, "and other women stepped forward with additional credible allegations of sexual harassment, it was obvious to everyone but his most hard-bitten defenders that Thomas would say anything to get his seat on the Court." I assume that by "credible" he means uncorroborated and hopelessly contradictory and that by "his most hard-bitten defenders" he means the 62% of Americans who supported Clarence Thomas's confirmation even after Ms. Hill's testimony.

title: The Glass Ceiling
summary: Despite being one of the most prolific and famous living composers, Philip Glass's work is rarely performed by major American orchestras.. But when the New York Philharmonic opened its new season on Wednesday with the premiere of Philip Glass's King Lear Overture, the event carried much symbolic weight. It was the first time the Philharmonic has commissioned a score by Mr. Glass, the 82-year-old giant of American music who has composed 12 symphonies and 13 concertos as part of his sprawling catalog that also includes operas and film scores, among other works. (Performances continue through Saturday.)

summary: The U.S. should focus on sanctions while letting the Saudis cope with any nasty local spillovers.. title: A Woman Doesn't Need an Office to Be Empowered
summary: A patient told me: 'I feel pressured to leave my children and return to meaningful work.'. Women's empowerment is usually equated with paid work outside the home. That's a mistake. A woman's value isn't only a matter of how much she can earn, and women's leadership should be understood to include nurturing.

title: The Mind vs. Brain, Is There a Difference?
summary: The mind is more than the sum of its neuronal connections.. Boldly provocative as it is, Michael S.A. Graziano's prediction that someday scientists will succeed in replicating the essentials of the human mind stems from a false premise-namely, that the brain and the mind are virtually identical ("Will Your Uploaded Mind Still Be You?," Review, Sept. 14). Research, experience and common sense tell us otherwise. The mind is more than the sum of its neuronal connections. It links us to external reality while at the same time creating our sense of who we are-what makes us different from everyone else. It has both objective (material) and subjective (immaterial) aspects. It understands the third law of thermodynamics but also recalls the cool breeze on a late summer's afternoon. While the mind no doubt operates inside the brain, it extends well beyond-in time and space-constantly engaging with the brains of other people, the surrounding environment and the larger culture. Without taking into consideration this larger framework, any attempt to duplicate the mind will ultimately come up short even after the centuries Dr. Graziano concedes it will take to make such a feat technologically possible.

title: Mighty Nimby Fights Building New Housing
summary: Higher density-turning every American city into a poor copy of Manhattan Island-isn't the solution to our housing problem.. As the former president of our neighborhood association in San Francisco, and then as president of a coalition of 20 neighborhood associations, I got used to being called a "Nimby" (not in my backyard) for trying to maintain single-family residential neighborhoods, which even today comprise a large part of the western part of the city. "The Weekend Interview with Kevin Faulconer: A Golden State Mayor Takes On the Nimbys" (by Mene Ukueberuwa, Sept. 14) is refreshing because the San Diego mayor is trying to increase housing without destroying single-family neighborhoods.

title: Trudeau Tries to Pivot Away From Controversy Over Blackface Images
summary: Seeking re-election, Canadian leader proposes ban on military-style assault rifles. After two days of apologies over photos showing him wearing blackface, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau tried to change the subject on Friday.

title: Hearing Aids Can Assist With More Than Speech
summary: A telecoil connects hearing aids wirelessly to induction hearing loops that transmit sound from public-address systems, stages, church pulpits and lecture halls as mandated by the Americans with Disabilities Act.. As a consumer advocate and audiologist, I feel compelled to write regarding "Hearing Aids Get Smarter," (Journal Report, Sept. 16). Experienced consumers will tell you that, besides Bluetooth technology, a telecoil should be on any list of must-have features. This inexpensive copper coil is available in even the most advanced instruments by the big-six hearing-aid companies. A telecoil connects hearing aids wirelessly to induction hearing loops that transmit sound from public-address systems, stages, church pulpits and lecture halls as mandated by the Americans with Disabilities Act and will overcome the shortcomings of tiny hearing-aid microphones. No pairing or linking is required, telecoils don't drain tiny hearing-aid batteries and, best of all, they work the same the world over-from the Sydney Opera House to the Gershwin Theatre in New York and the London taxi cabs.

summary: Evolving from the pavement-scraping speed demons McLaren has always unleashed, the new GT-series of cars will be the first into which one can fit a golf bag or a pair of skis. BERLIN-Germany unveiled an array of climate policies Friday designed to curb greenhouse gas emissions that economists said were unlikely to provide much of a boost to the country's flagging economy, despite a projected €54 billion ($60 billion) price tag between now and 2030.

title: An Ancient Practice Transformed by the Arrival of Europeans
summary: Slavery existed in Africa long before Columbus, but the trans-Atlantic trade turned it into a very different institution. Long before Christopher Columbus sailed to the New World, various forms of slavery flourished in Europe and Africa. But these Old World practices differed in important ways from the types of slavery that developed in the Americas after the institution of the Atlantic slave trade in the 1500s. New World slavery was a racialized institution in which slaves were black and slave owners were white. In contrast, owners and slaves in the Old World were generally of the same race. Distinctions between enslaved and freeborn people were often framed not in racial terms but in terms of language, culture and religion. The Greeks enslaved people whom they considered barbarians, and both Christians and Muslims in the Middle Ages enslaved people whom they regarded as infidels. Slaves were seen above all as outsiders who lacked a social identity in their new community.

title: You're Probably Washing Your Face Wrong
summary: As our skin-care routines grow ever more elaborate, here's the latest in cleansing wisdom from dermatologists and facialists.. MY 94-YEAR-OLD grandmother has only ever washed her face with warm water or, when she's feeling fancy, the original Noxzema cold cream, which she'll scoop out of the blue tub with her fingers, apply in a thick layer, and then gingerly tissue off. Her skin is luminous. But most dermatologists would likely cringe at her technique. While face-washing seems like it should be one of our more mindless beauty exercises-wash, rinse, move on-as we've become more obsessive about our skin care regimens, it has taken on greater importance. And, under this new scrutiny, the question has arisen: Are we doing it wrong?

title: When the Slave Traders Were African
summary: Resume Subscription. This August marked 400 years since the first documented enslaved Africans arrived in the U.S. In 1619, a ship reached the Jamestown settlement in the colony of Virginia, carrying "some 20 and odd Negroes" who were kidnapped from their villages in present-day Angola. The anniversary coincides with a controversial debate in the U.S. about whether the country owes reparations to the descendants of slaves as compensation for centuries of injustice and inequality. It is a moment for posing questions of historic guilt and responsibility.

title: 'Bosom Friends' Review: 'Buck' & His 'Better Half'
summary: Some say James Buchanan was the first gay president, pointing to his friendship with former senatorial colleague William R. King. Whatever the nature of their bond, its fruits were clear: a pro-slavery agenda that shaped pre-Civil War politics.. At the end of his life, with the scars of civil war unhealed and Lincoln's "new birth of freedom" coming under daily assault from his white-supremacist successor, James Buchanan (1791-1868), America's 15th president (1857-61), insisted he had nothing to apologize for. "History will vindicate my memory," the dying man assured a visitor to Wheatland, his faux "plantation estate" in Pennsylvania Dutch country. As lacking in prophetic gifts as in crisis management, Buchanan would in fact become synonymous with executive failure. More recently the first line of his historical obituary has been revised, with the obligatory America's Worst President dropped in favor of America's First (and only?) Gay President.

title: The Long History of American Slavery Reparations
summary: Resume Subscription. During the colonial era, it was customary for masters to grant "freedom dues" to indentured servants who had completed their fixed term of service. They were given land at times but at the very least tools and livestock to help begin their new lives in freedom. When former slaves demanded land after the Civil War, they were harking back to this longtime custom, which the rest of the country (with the exception of the abolitionists) had long forgotten. Since the Reconstruction era, the reneged-upon promise of reparations-recompense to African-Americans for centuries of enslavement and racial oppression-has continued to fester like an open sore on the nation's body politic.

title: 'The Dutch House' Review: Family Treason
summary: Ann Patchett's novel follows two siblings deprived of their family home by a seemingly wicked stepmother.. The dominant figure in Ann Patchett's new novel, "The Dutch House," is in many ways the house itself, a captivating childhood home that later becomes, as one character puts it, "the hero of every story, our lost and beloved country." Like the Flyte family's castle in Evelyn Waugh's "Brideshead Revisited," this grandiose mansion holds the past entombed and its inhabitants enthralled. But the Dutch House is also unmistakably American. Built with tobacco money in an era when "ready-made cigarettes lined up in their cartons were a luxury for the rich, as were acres never walked on by the people who owned them," this 1920s Pennsylvania residence seems constructed of glass and light. "Not only could you see into the Dutch House," the narrator explains of its vast windows, "from the driveway you could let your eye go up the front steps . . . across the long marble floor of the foyer, through the observatory, and catch sight of the lilacs waving obliviously in the garden behind the house."

title: 'The Second Founding' and 'Equality: An American Dilemma, 1866-1896' Review: Replanting Democracy
summary: Reconstruction was only part of an effort to rebuild American society on egalitarian terms.. The idea of personal and political equality has always been celebrated in American tradition, but it was at best only fitfully sustained in the pre-Civil War era. In practice, the individual states could legislate as they wished with respect to their inhabitants and to exclude virtually anyone-slaves, free blacks, women, paupers, non-property owners-from citizenship and equal treatment before the law. After the Civil War, however, Radical Republicans in Congress embarked on a bold campaign to erect a new egalitarian society on the ruins of slavery.

title: Fiction Review: The Forgotten Women Warriors of Abyssinia
summary: Dramatizing the tenacious resistance to Italy's invasion of Ethiopia, Maaza Mengiste's new novel shines light on an often-overlooked conflict.. In the midst of Italy's 1935 invasion of Ethiopia, Benito Mussolini's 19-year-old son Vittorio, a pilot in the Regia Aeronautica, published an account of an air raid, writing, "I still remember the effect I produced on a small group of Galla tribesmen massed around a man in black clothes. I dropped an aerial torpedo right in the center, and the group opened up just like a flowering rose. It was most entertaining."

title: 'The Meritocracy Trap' Review: Squeezing Through the Narrow Door
summary: The acquisition of status and wealth strictly on merit would seem to be a democratic ideal. In practice, a new book argues, it has been a disaster for America.. "The Meritocracy Trap" is a work in the line of Thorstein Veblen's "The Theory of the Leisure Class" (1899), John Kenneth Galbraith's "The Affluent Society" (1958) and Michael Harrington's "The Other America" (1962). Combining economics and sociology, two less than promising fields of intellectual endeavor, these books attempted to describe an underlying reality of American life that at the time was not fully understood by Americans themselves. How the rich live, the disparities between wealth in the nation's private sector and poverty in its public sector, the shockingly large number of Americans living in poverty, such were the themes of these earlier books. "The Meritocracy Trap" takes for its theme another less than fully understood reality in American life: the advance of an elite class causing the submergence of the middle class, and the dispiriting effect of this on the life of the nation.

title: Mysteries: Hunting the Elevator Executioner
summary: In Linwood Barclay's startling and witty thriller, someone is tampering with elevators in New York City high-rises and sending passengers plummeting to their deaths.. Who is tampering with elevators in New York City's high-rise buildings to fatal effect-and why? Those are the urgent questions faced by public officials in Linwood Barclay's suspenseful and satirical "Elevator Pitch" (Morrow, 453 pages, $26.99). Perhaps a lone techie with a private grudge is to blame. Or a member of an organized terrorist group. "To go to all this trouble," reasons a Homeland Security man, "you can bet your ass there's a reason. Even if it's one that might not make sense to us."

title: 'The Accusation' Review: Hysteria on Main Street
summary: Little Barbara Griffiths briefly disappeared 91 years ago this week, and for the first time the "blood libel" spread through a U.S. town.. Sometimes history gushes from a few places, and the historian has to sort and sift. Sometimes it's more dispersed, and one's principal job is tracking it down. And sometimes it's lost or seems so, either because it was never recorded or preserved or died with the people who lived it.

title: 'You Don't Have to Face It Alone.' Hong Kong Protests Propelled by Hidden Support Network
summary: Resume Subscription. HONG KONG-Most nights, when Hong Kong fogs up with tear gas and black-shirted young protesters find themselves on the run from police, a middle-aged manager named Mr. Chan drives his silver Toyota four-door into the fray to ferry them home.

title: Five Best: Sara Collins on Crime Novels
summary: From the author of "The Confessions of Frannie Langton.". By John Banville (1989)

title: James Challenger Helped Create Market for Outplacement Services
summary: Chicago entrepreneur persuaded firms it was in their interest to help people on the way out the door. James Challenger had tried law, advertising and manufacturing of gas heaters before dreaming up in the mid-1960s what he called a wild idea: persuading companies to pay him to help find new jobs for executives and middle managers they were laying off.

title: Children's Books: Little Lords and Princesses
summary: Frances Hodgson Burnett's novels feature imperfect, distinct characters, including children who suffer sharp reversals of fortune.. Like many young readers, I could never see the point of scholarly introductions to classic texts. Why would anyone want to slog through pages of reflection and criticism written by some tiresome academic when the story was right there, waiting to be devoured? I didn't imagine that I might one day let the pages of a thick volume spin under my thumb as I searched in vain for that once most odious of beginnings.

title: Arch Rivals Quarrel Over Quirky Geological Formations
summary: Resume Subscription. ESCALANTE, Utah-Jens Munthe powers headlong through shoulder-high brush in a river canyon flanked by towering cliffs while he looks out for empty spaces in the rocks around him.

title: Fairness in Housework Doesn't Mean 50/50
summary: Happiness at home comes from each spouse owning tasks completely-not dividing everything exactly down the middle. Some of my dearest friends and I met in downtown Los Angeles one Saturday morning to join a march to honor breast cancer survivors. As we walked through the streets in pink leggings, chanting, "Courage, strength and power," it felt like a true girlfriends' getaway with high-energy sisterhood in the air. That is, until the first text message came through around noon: When are you coming home?

title: Vanguard Bets on Robo-Only Adviser
summary: Money manager is aiming to capture younger, tech-savvy investors. Indexing giant Vanguard Group plans to launch a robo-advisory service that cuts out human financial advisers completely.

title: St. Greta Spreads the Climate Gospel
summary: A movement that believes in sin, penance and salvation doesn't sound very scientific. It's been noted before that the cause of addressing climate change has become something like the modern world's version of a secular religion. In much of Europe especially, but in sections of American society too, a kind of climate theology has replaced traditional Christianity as the ultimate source of authority over human behavior, comprising both an all-embracing teleology of our existence and a prescriptive moral code.

title: Taiwan Loses Another Diplomatic Tie, as China Continues Isolation Push
summary: Kiribati becomes second Pacific nation in less than a week to switch allegiance to Beijing from Taipei. BEIJING-Kiribati has become the second Pacific nation in less than a week to end diplomatic relations with Taipei and switch allegiance to Beijing, reflecting China's strategic gains in the region while squeezing an increasingly isolated Taiwan.

title: Market for Illicit Vaping Products Flourishes Online
summary: WSJ review finds cannabis-vaping products and tools to create counterfeits on major websites. As concerns about the health hazards of vaping mount, a market for illicit cannabis-vaping products and the tools to create counterfeits is thriving online.

title: Fanny Packs for the Great Outdoors, Not Fashion Runways
summary: Though designer labels like Gucci have attempted to co-opt the humble belt bag, these workhorse fanny packs are built for sporty sorts. I REGRET TO INFORM you that the fanny pack is decidedly uncool.

title: Whitey Bulger's Family Files Claim Against Federal Government
summary: Questions remain unanswered about mobster's death, family says.

title: Market Calling the Clock On Tech Unicorns
summary: More unicorns will need to risk the public markets. Luckily, We Co.'s fire hasn't burned them all.. The clock appears to be ticking on the days in which technology companies losing billions of dollars are valued at tens of billions in the public market. That realization may be forcing the hand of today's unicorns-for better or for worse.

title: Lively and Intimate Likenesses
summary: John Singer Sargent's charcoal portraits captured the great and the good. John Singer Sargent could be a noisy dervish while drawing portraits, whirling around the studio and sputtering in frustration as he jabbed a nub of charcoal at the paper on his easel. He made noises like a "kettle on the hearth," wrote British aristocrat Cynthia Asquith, whom Sargent drew in 1909. More than 50 likenesses are in a new exhibit, "John Singer Sargent: Portraits in Charcoal," which will be on view at the Morgan Library and Museum in New York from Oct. 4, 2019, through Jan. 12, 2020, before opening at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington on Feb. 28.

title: Harris Takes Risky Iowa-or-Bust Tack
summary: Every cycle some presidential candidates focus all their attention on Iowa, to mixed results. Kamala Harris's campaign says she is focusing her efforts on Iowa in the hopes of reviving her struggling campaign.

title: AT&T Boss Met With Activist to Discuss Strategy
summary: Telecom chief Randall Stephenson and hedge fund critic Jesse Cohn discussed streamlining. AT&T Inc.'s chief executive met this week with the activist investor who is pressing the company to rethink its strategy and sell off more assets, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: The Disappearing Political Center: In More Places, Elections Aren't Close
summary: A comparison of Bill Clinton's re-election in 1996 with Donald Trump's victory 20 years later. For a stark illustration of how the political center is disappearing from American politics, compare President Bill Clinton's re-election in 1996 with Donald Trump's victory 20 years later.

title: Stocks to Watch: U.S. Steel, Datadog, Altria, Tegna and More
summary: Resume Subscription. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: This Dog Will Hunt
summary: Datadog spurning pre-IPO buyout offer pays off. Dogs aren't known for patience, but Datadog proved that two birds in the bush are sometimes worth waiting for.

title: Trump, Australian Prime Minister Look to Reinforce an at-Times Strained Alliance
summary: Scott Morrison attends a rare state visit at the White House. WASHINGTON-President Trump is hosting Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison for a White House state visit, with the goal of reinforcing a longtime alliance that has faced some recent challenges.

title: Gail Simmons on Setting Boundaries with Your Money and Time
summary: The cookbook author and 'Top Chef' judge shares how she turned her passions into the career of her dreams in 'Secrets of Wealthy Women podcast'. When you're financially successful, friends and family may ask you to lend them money or invest in their businesses.

title: Saudi Oil Attacks Could Halt Natural-Gas Rally
summary: A boost in U.S. drilling means pumping supply into an already-flooded market. Natural-gas prices have recovered from their summer swoon, but analysts and investors are skeptical that the gains will last, particularly after the weekend attacks on Saudi oil facilities.

title: The Georgia Bulldogs Want to Wreak Havoc on Opponents
summary: Bulldogs football coach Kirby Smart says he wants his defense to cause chaos on at least 20% of its plays. In the three months Georgia football coach Kirby Smart spent stewing after his team's 28-21 Sugar Bowl loss to Texas in January, he came up with a novel idea to improve his defense: a Socratic dialogue about havoc with a locker room full of college football players.

title: Pulisic Is the Future of U.S. Soccer. England Isn't Convinced.
summary: In his first season at Chelsea, the 21-year-old U.S. star faces stiff competition from players just like him. LONDON-American soccer has never known a 21-year-old quite as polished-or quite as expensive-as Christian Pulisic. When he signed with Chelsea in January for $73 million, he more than doubled the record transfer fee for a player from the U.S. His move to the Premier League was the leap that everyone had always sensed was coming.

title: Rest Easy: The Fed Isn't Losing Control of Money Markets
summary: Banks' short-term funding costs registered an alarming spike this week, but this just reflects a return to precrisis central banking. For lovers of the minutiae of monetary-policy plumbing, this week's snafu in the money market is fascinating. For everyone else, it probably doesn't matter.

title: How Renée Zellweger Became Judy Garland
summary: Preparing to play the iconic performer involved throwing chairs, FaceTiming nightly with her vocal coach and staying in character on set. Preparing to play late-1960s Judy Garland in this month's upcoming biopic Judy, Renée Zellweger says she had nights where she got very little sleep, not unlike her character in the film. While Garland's insomnia was thought to have been caused by the prescription pills she was addicted to, Zellweger was kept awake by her research, captivated by the person she was about to portray. "When you're trying to come to know a person whom you've never met, there are tiny little things that you're mining for," she says. "I just kept wanting to find the next."

title: Goldman, China's Sovereign-Wealth Fund Invest in U.S. Manufacturing
summary: But China Investment Corp. says trade-war tensions will make it more cautious about further investments. BEIJING-China's sovereign-wealth fund has started investing in the U.S. manufacturing sector through a joint venture with Goldman Sachs Group Inc., but warned it would be more cautious about the American market because of the trade war.

title: North Korea Names Nuclear Negotiator
summary: Kim Myong Gil calls President Trump's removal of 'nasty troublemaker' John Bolton wise. SEOUL-North Korea named a veteran diplomat with extensive U.S. experience as its chief negotiator for working-level talks with Washington, while praising President Trump for dismissing national security adviserJohn Bolton.

title: Indian Prime Minister Modi, in Visit to U.S., Seeks to Ease Trade Tensions
summary: Despite broader overall ties, President Trump complains the country hasn't opened its market sufficiently to American goods. India may loosen restrictions impeding U.S. goods as Prime Minister Narendra Modi heads to the U.S. for a week-including a planned appearance with President Trump in Houston-in an effort to damp simmering trade tensions and garner fresh investment into its flagging economy, according to Indian officials.

title: Japan's Mitsubishi Says Rogue Oil Trader Lost $320 Million
summary: The trading house said it has fired the Singapore-based employee and filed a complaint with the police. Japan's Mitsubishi Corp. said a subsidiary has lost about $320 million on energy derivatives, after a rogue employee in Singapore entered into secret unauthorized trades and then lost money as crude prices fell.

title: Why Hong Kong's Currency Is Still Rock Solid
summary: Hong Kong's currency-board arrangement has served it well and isn't going anywhere. When the future of Hong Kong was hanging in the balance during Sino-British handover talks, the city's currency lost around a third of its value against the dollar in just 12 months. The Hong Kong government then decided in 1983 to peg its currency to the dollar to restore confidence. The exchange-rate system put in place then should once again weather the turmoil the city is facing.

title: Are High-School Girls Really Abandoning Basketball?
summary: Annual survey that counts high-school sports participation relies on self-reporting, and some guesswork. Why would 13,000 high-school girls suddenly quit basketball, as the latest High School Athletics Participation Survey suggests happened last year?

title: Apple's Triple Shot May Add Some Kick
summary: Launch of newest iPhones may fare well against low official expectations. By all accounts, Apple Inc. is expected to have another dud year of iPhone sales. Ironically, that may work out well for the company as its three new phones hit stores on Friday.

title: Mastering the Art of Impatience
summary: Need better efforts on short timetables? Start by giving a damn.. Three a.m. phone calls are rarely welcome. A few have come my way over two decades of reporting, but the one that woke me in the summer of 2006 left a mark.

title: Nintendo Seeks to Sustain Switch Sales With Stripped-Down Console
summary: Japanese videogame maker introduces the $200 Switch Lite as it gears up for heightened competition from Sony, Microsoft. TOKYO- Nintendo Co. introduced a stripped-down Switch console, meant to keep up the line's momentum in its third holiday season, as the videogame maker seeks to widen the Nintendo brand's global presence.

title: China Detains Former U.S. Air Force Pilot Flying for FedEx
summary: Pilot had nonmetallic air gun pellets in checked luggage; authorities allege he was transporting ammunition illegally. HONG KONG-Chinese authorities have detained a FedEx Corp. pilot in the southern city of Guangzhou, elevating pressure on the express shipping giant that is already in Beijing's crosshairs amid a U.S.-China trade war.

title: DeVos Family Office Affiliate to Buy Stake in Nordic Capital
summary: Nordic Capital will use a cash injection from a unit of RDV Corp., the family office of a clan that includes Betsy and Richard DeVos, to strengthen its balance sheet. The latest deal in the booming market for private-equity firm stakes has gone to an unusual buyer: the DeVos family office.

title: Political Control in Virginia Up for Grabs in Tight Election
summary: Democrats seek to flip both houses of legislature, reviving gun-control efforts made after a May mass shooting. ASHBURN, Va.-Democrats are banking on this affluent, fast-growing suburb of Washington, D.C., to help the party claim simultaneous control of Virginia's legislative and executive branches for the first time in a quarter-century.

title: Sanders's 'Revolution' in Burlington: Working With GOP, Business
summary: Resume Subscription. BURLINGTON, Vt.-Bernie Sanders says that if he is elected president, he will convince skeptics to support his agenda by building a movement so powerful that they will have no choice but to join him.

title: Harris Takes Aim at a Rising Warren
summary: Democratic presidential hopeful faults rival's fundraising, and Georgia Republicans tell governor to 'just make a pick' for a new senator. KAMALA HARRIS, now a distant fourth in the Democratic presidential race, took aim at poll-climber Elizabeth Warren for doing big-money events. In response to a question about Warren, Harris said at a closed-door fundraiser it was hypocritical for her rival to claim she wasn't taking money from large donors when Warren transferred around $10 million from her Senate funds before denouncing big money donations. Harris moved $1.2 million into her presidential fund. Harris lamented that she now needs to be in places like New York to keep the campaign financially afloat but prefers to spend time in early voting states.

title: Powell's Subtle Messaging to Trump on Trade Fight
summary: Fed chairman mentioned trade 20 times at his news conference on Wednesday. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's press conference this week carried a subtle message for President Trump: If you're worried about an economic slowdown, find a way to cool down the trade war.

title: 'I'm Not Your Therapist.' What's the Point of an Executive Coach?
summary: Having your own Wendy Rhoades can be a badge of honor, but as lines blur some see problems. A big one: no legal confidentiality protection.. In the middle of a family crisis, Aishetu Fatima Dozie, a Harvard Business School graduate, decided to call her executive coach. The two had grown close, and it wasn't unusual for personal matters to come up during sessions. The conversation made her feel better, but apparently it crossed a line.

title: The Unexpected Consequences of Being Too Optimistic About Growth
summary: In a slow economy, investors appear to be setting a high bar for improvements in corporate earnings. Bad things can happen when companies try to hit unrealistic targets.. And you had such potential!

title: U.S. Needs to Do More on 5G, Senator Says
summary: Sen. Mark Warner: American companies might need government help to compete with China on new wireless technology. The U.S. should consider adopting Beijing's tactics to stay ahead in the global race to deploy 5G, the next generation of wireless technology, Sen. Mark Warner (D., Va.) said Thursday.

title: Bondholders Stranded as HNA-Backed Airport Defaults
summary: Haikou Meilan's bond is the eighth Asian dollar bond to default this year. In a departure from HNA Group Co.'s record of paying back international bondholders despite its financial constraints, an airport partly owned by units of the Chinese conglomerate has failed to repay holders of its dollar bonds on time.

title: Donor to Pay Off Morehouse College Parents' Debts Along With Students'
summary: Billionaire Robert F. Smith says he will wipe out loans parents took on to pay for children's education. Robert F. Smith, the private-equity billionaire who pledged to wipe out the student-loan debt of the class of 2019 at Morehouse College, will cover debt taken on by the students' parents as well.

title: U.S.-Mexico Tomato Deal Could Force Retailers, Importers to Play Ketchup
summary: Deal requires USDA to inspect round, Roma and bulk grape tomatoes. WASHINGTON-The U.S. finalized a deal with Mexican tomato growers that American retailers and importers warn could lead to more expensive and lower-quality tomatoes at the supermarket.

title: Trump Administration Resumes Deportation Relief for Immigrants With Serious Illnesses
summary: It reverses earlier move to end applications from people seeking to stay in the U.S. for lifesaving treatment. WASHINGTON-The Department of Homeland Security will once more consider requests from unauthorized immigrants to temporarily stay in the country, typically to receive lifesaving medical treatment, after facing fierce criticism for announcing that it would no longer accept such appeals.

title: Rain From Tropical Storm Inundates Parts of Texas
summary: Some areas have seen as much as 42 inches since Imelda began approaching. HOUSTON-Two men died in southeast Texas Thursday amid flooding that shut down some roads and the airport in Houston and forced rescuers to evacuate people around Beaumont, 80 miles to the east, authorities said.

title: For a Truly Indulgent Vacation, Fly Solo
summary: Once, only intrepid travelers vacationed alone. Now, all sorts-and not just single people-are traveling solo. And hotels, cruises and tour operators are easing the way. LAST AUTUMN Meg Leahy, mother of two and a museum registrar in Washington, D.C., realized she'd be alone without her family for a long weekend. Spontaneously, she booked a ticket to Mexico City, a part of the country she'd never visited. The trip seemed likely to be lonely: She knew only one person in the city, vaguely at best. But she was determined.

title: Democratic Donor Charged in Fatal Overdose
summary: Contributor in California is accused of providing methamphetamine to man who died in 2017. A prominent Los Angeles donor to the Democratic Party is facing a federal charge related to one of two fatal drug overdoses in his apartment since 2017, prosecutors said Thursday.

title: Zuckerberg Meets With Trump, Faces Tough Questions from Senators
summary: Facebook CEO came to Washington seeking to placate lawmakers scrutinizing big tech. WASHINGTON-With his company under a regulatory spotlight, Facebook Inc. Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg scored a meeting at the White House with President Trump Thursday-but faced a chillier reception from lawmakers on Capitol Hill.

title: Los Angeles Dodgers Add Two Entrepreneurs to Ownership Team
summary: Alan Smolinisky and Robert Plummer join investor group that includes basketball legend Magic Johnson. The Los Angeles Dodgers added Alan Smolinisky and Robert Plummer to the team's ownership group, whose members include financial-management executive Mark Walter and basketball legend Magic Johnson, people familiar with the matter said.

title: PG&E Bondholders Ally With Fire Victims to Offer New Bankruptcy Plan
summary: Bondholders offer cash and equity to pay wildfire claims at $24 billion. Bondholders are taking another run at PG&E Corp. , forming an alliance with victims of the wildfires that swept through California in 2017 and 2018 to chart a path out of bankruptcy for the state's largest utility.

title: Datadog Shares Soar as Investors Bet on Cloud-Based Software
summary: Company's stock surges in initial trading. Shares of Datadog Inc. jumped as they made their debut in the public markets, reflecting robust investor demand for companies tied to cloud-based technologies.

title: Behind the GM-UAW Strike: Two Combatants With Something to Prove
summary: Resume Subscription. For months, leaders of both the United Auto Workers and General Motors Co. were desperate for a win.

title: As GM Strike Stretches On, Supply Chain Starts to Suffer
summary: Automotive suppliers idle plants and lay off workers; 'it goes right to the bottom line'. Companies that supply parts to General Motors Co. are being forced to idle plants and lay off workers, as the national strike called by the United Auto Workers completes its fourth day.
